instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message:
Hi guys,


This one works normally without the battery and also works normally when the battery is connected. BUT when the battery is connected and you plugin the magsafe the green light trembles and switches off. You must remove the magsafe from the AC outlet to start it again because it has detected a short.

I tried all the usual suspects to no avail.


a) <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> was replaced.

b) All surrounding resistors were measured OK => IMPORTANT NOTE: <RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR> was measuring 55K in-circuit (instead of 220K) but was the SAME ALSO OFF-CIRCUIT. So I placed a new 220K in its place and now it is measuring 220K IN-CIRCUIT (this was a question of another user in another topic and Louis said its because the resistor is in-circuit but probably this one is measuring right)! nothing changed.

c) <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> was found to be "always open" or shorted between S & D and was replaced. nothing changed.

d) <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> & <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> were also replaced incase there were not driven properly by their Gates.

e) new battery and original 85W magsafe used.


At this point I could use some insight from the gurus.

br,
george

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message:
with magsafe only: 16.4 to 16.5V
with battery only: 11.9 to 12.0V measured at F7040

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message:
Are you sure ppbus is 16.5v with magsafe only?
If so PPBUS seems shorted to ppdcin.
Problem with ISL/ transistor buck converter not stepping down or anything between ppdcin and ppbus.
Try replacing ISL and mosfets all at once just in case.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message: PPDCIN at F6905 is 16.8V, then <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 16.4-16.6V at F7040. What do you mean?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message:
I mean with magsafe only <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is too high, it should be 12,6V not 16.4-16.6V. The only rail around 16V-17V is PPDCIN.
Whats is resistance between F6905 and F7040?  Between Pins 1 and 5 at <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message: of course you are right <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is ridiculous at 16.6V!.. <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> seems shorted between 1-5. will replace that and report.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message: thats what happens when you miss the basics.. thank you dude. problem solved. note that I missed two things. one the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> correct value and also the short at <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> which I measured. need a holiday.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message:
Glad you fixed it. What was tricky I think in your case, is that the board worked with ppdcin on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Usually when the fan spins we don't give a shit about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> :)
So I learned that a board at least <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> could work with PPDCIN shorted to PPBUS without battery.
Hope your battery and  sense resistors are still ok.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> weird charging problem - Shorts <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL> when batt is connected.
threads.message: yes and I think that is the reason I oversaw the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> value - my brain played a dirty game on me. Everything is great so far. thank you again buddy.
